Description: The New York Attorney General announced an agreement with Arbitron, the second largest media ratings service, requiring the company to overhaul its system for determining radio ratings in New York in response to allegations that minority listeners were undercounted. Under the agreement, Arbitron was required to pay $260,000 to the state, make a contribution of $100,000 to the National Association of Black Owned Broadcasters and the Spanish Radio Association to support minority radio and fund an advertising campaign of at least $25,000 dedicated to promoting minority radio.

The California Attorney General announced a settlement with Arbitron Inc., the nation's dominant provider of radio audience ratings, over allegations that the method it used to collect ratings information discriminated against radio stations with predominantly African-American and Latino audiences.
